channel.title: MyText - Open Source Framework: Updated
channel.description:
Since 'Java Text' isn't open source, I decided to make my own base for java based text games. I haven't used java in a very long time, so this helped me remember a few things. I made sure that I commented everything too, in the attempt to teach a few things. Anyways, make sure you open it with wordpad, not notepad, otherwise it will not display correctly. It's also noteworthy to know that the program doesn't close if you enter an invalid command.
[b]Contents[/b] [u]Contracting[/u] [i]- Lets the user do contracts. Selects a random item and gives a value of to 12. The users gets payed the amount the items are worth, plus a little extra.[/i] [u]Event Management[/u] [i]- Allows events to be run on a new thread, over and over.[/i] [u]Investments[/u][i] - Uses Events. If you have money invested, every minute you will gain or loose money.[/i] [u]Skills[/u] [i]- Firemaking, Woodcutting, Mining, Smithing.[/i] [u]Autosave[/u][i] - If activated, every minute-and-a-half, your game is automatically saved.[/i] [u]Shop[/u] [i]- Complete shopping.[/i] [u]Security[/u][i] - A new implementation that activates whenever a user types certain tracked phrases at around the same time. After 3 reports, the user is given a random phrase to enter. If failed, a blackmark is added to the user. 4 black-marks an the users account is reset. [/i] [b]Downloads[/b] New- [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?jbpgrdjac3d4cap]Compiled Project to Play[/url] [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?ibkskxpexpy38l2]Netbeans Project Files[/url]
Old- [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?4ojqcwl82k9cslz]Compiled Project to Play[/url] [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?tqzsb432boeq5hr]NetBeans Project Files[/url]
Lol. Enjoy :cool:.

item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“Wyrmcabbage, post:30, topic:389451”]Just because you people “know Java”, it gives you no reason to go around acting like you’re Gods. I know plenty Java, but I believe that you fucktards are just too wrapped up in your own arrogance to realize that there are some people less knowledgeable than you. I may be more experienced in something else than you guys, so I’d shut my cock-holster and stop assuming that I’m better than everyone else. Ddosd tried to make a contribution - one fucking contribution! - but then you guys started ranting about “conventions, polymorphism, etc.”. For fuck’s sake, realize that there’s someone else here trying to make a contribution and stop going on about how much you know more than them and that they should change this, this and that. At least he posted something, you guys didn’t, so fuck off until you prove you’re any smarter than ddosd.

FUCK, that felt good. Goodbye, Mopar. Your community truly does suck big ones.[/quote]I’ve seen you quit a few times, I fail to believe it’s true this time. Anyway, the fact that we pointed out conventions and shit (since you know java so well) should just go to prove that we were helping him. If you can’t program by the conventions you really shouldn’t program.

item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

[quote=“Wyrmcabbage, post:14, topic:389451”]you suck.

Also, if it requires comments to explain what’s going on, it’s bad code.

documentation of procedure and practice is hardly a bad thing, i’d rather be able to look at a basic synopsis than decipher someone else’s code, even if the code is fine.

I program daily. I go to college, major in Software Development daily. I study with multiple professors who all have 30+ years of programming experience. I’m pretty sure I’m going to believe what they say over someone whose majority of “programming experience” revolves around a video game. I’m done with you. Honestly no need to continue on with such a hopeless argument. Read a bit more please.

no one cares what your professor can do, the likelihood that their experience and ability reflects yours is next to nothing, and nothing is a word that your ability is, quite probably, little more than.

You are most definitely a troll. That is what disappoints me about mitb and moparscape alike - the high amount of people who think they know everything and like to rub it in less experienced peoples’ faces.

You, sir, fail. I’m sorry, but I don’t care how much you know, it gives you no reason to go around acting like God. Good day.
Thanks for listening :D[/quote]

Last I recall, from looking at recent posts on moparisthebest, you know nothing about Java.

item.title: MyText - Open Source Framework: Updated
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:19, topic:389451”][quote author=_s link=topic=485372.msg3558296#msg3558296 date=1302051846]

Whats your issue with the majority of the people on this site _s?

i have no issue with most, but Wyrmcabbage is just annoyingly ignorant and zyle1992 is under the influence he’s worth something.
[/quote]

I’ve just been trained that the only comments that are required, are Javadoc type comments. I’ve been taught to split code up into usable chunks(methods, etc). Upon reviewing my comment I realise that it was improperly worded.

Comments aren’t required, but are useful for explaining parts of code that may be hard to follow. Line by line comments, are erroneous. But properly documenting methods(via Javadoc or something similar), splitting up code into different methods, and appropriate method and field names keeps the amount of comments down to a minimum.

Here are some examples:

int a = 0;// total sum
int b = 2;// step size
for(int i = 0; i < 20; i+= b) {
    a += i * b;// increase sum
}

This type of code, although documented well, should be rewritten instead of having comments explaining what’s going on.

int sum = 0;
int stepSize = 2;
for(int i = 0; i < 20; i += stepSize) {
    sum += i * stepSize;
}

That code is easier to follow, and doesn’t require comments, because the field names make it self documenting.[/quote]

self documentation is a good thing in code, but it, by no means, gives one an excuse to omit documentation entirely. i’ll agree that documenting every single line in a method can get annoying if the line of code is something like a trivial declaration or a simple expression, but if the programmer likes it that way then so be it. over-documentation isn’t a crime nor is it erroneous, it’s merely over-documentation and a plus of this practice is that it displays an adept commandeering of the forward slash button.

and i also agree that javadoc documentation can be useful, it provides a nice little synopsis however i do feel that, generally and from personal experience, it seems to lack in details of implementation and maybe, in ones strife to understand the implementation, a little bit of black wizardry is used that really should be commented on, by all means should commenting be used here; extensively if required.

Read full topic

[/quote]

i have no issue with most, but Wyrmcabbage is just annoyingly ignorant and zyle1992 is under the influence he’s worth something.[/quote]

I’ve just been trained that the only comments that are required, are Javadoc type comments. I’ve been taught to split code up into usable chunks(methods, etc). Upon reviewing my comment I realise that it was improperly worded.

Comments aren’t required, but are useful for explaining parts of code that may be hard to follow. Line by line comments, are erroneous. But properly documenting methods(via Javadoc or something similar), splitting up code into different methods, and appropriate method and field names keeps the amount of comments down to a minimum.

Here are some examples:

int a = 0;// total sum
int b = 2;// step size
for(int i = 0; i < 20; i+= b) {
    a += i * b;// increase sum
}

This type of code, although documented well, should be rewritten instead of having comments explaining what’s going on.

int sum = 0;
int stepSize = 2;
for(int i = 0; i < 20; i += stepSize) {
    sum += i * stepSize;
}

That code is easier to follow, and doesn’t require comments, because the field names make it self documenting.

Unfortunately, due to my improper wording I seem to have sparked some flaming. It was not my intention. I apologise for this.

item.title: MyText - Open Source Framework: Updated
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Wyrmcabbage, post:2, topic:389451”]HUGE thanks for this

I’m using it now, and I must say it is well made. I won’t be playing so much as I’ll be improving upon it. If I make any games with this, I’ll be sure to give credit!

EDIT: Added fun stuff… cheats!

Make a new class named “Cheats”, I put it in a package called remo.additions, or you could put it in ddosd.game (and remove the import remo.additions.Cheats statement). Copy this there:

[code=java5]package remo.additions;

import java.util.Scanner;

import ddosd.game.Engine;
import ddosd.user.Player;

public class Cheats {
static int cash;
static Engine engine = new Engine();

public static void askForCheats() {
	methods.log("Please enter the cheat you'd like to exploit...\nPlease note that no cheats are listed :D Ask Wyrmcabbage on Moparscape if you want some. :D");
	String cheat = Engine.getInput();
	if(cheat.equals("lolmakemerich!@#$%^&*")){
		Coins();
	} else {
		methods.log("Cheat not recognized.");
	}
}
public static void Coins() {
        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
        methods.log("How many coins would you like to add?");
        String much = scan.nextLine();
        
        try {
        	cash = Integer.parseInt(much);
        } catch (NumberFormatException nfe) {methods.log("That's no number...?");}  
		Player.addItem("Coins", much.substring(1));
            methods.log("You're rich now! :D\n...Cheater...");
            System.out.format("You just got: %,d", cash);
            System.out.println(" coins.");
            try {
            	Thread.sleep(750);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {}
            engine.doStart();
      }
}
}

[/code]
Go ahead and add cheats in that same syntax…

Then, copy everything in Engine and post this:

[code=java5]package ddosd.game;

import ddosd.io.FileOperations;
import remo.additions.Cheats;
import ddosd.skills.Mining;
import ddosd.skills.Woodcut;
import ddosd.user.Contract;
import ddosd.user.Player;

import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;

import remo.additions.methods;
import ddosd.user.Player;

/**

  • This is our engine class. This will do almost everything.

  • It will read and react to user input, using other classes.

  • Without this class, the game will not work at all.

  • @author Andrew (aka. ddosd)
    */
    public class Engine {

    /**

    • Our player.
      /
      public Player player = new Player();
      /      *
    • Mining class.
      /
      public Mining mining = new Mining();
      /      *
    • Shopping class.
      /
      public Shop shop = new Shop();
      /      *
    • File operations class.
      /
      public FileOperations fileops = new FileOperations();
      /      *
    • Contracting class.
      /
      public Contract contract = new Contract();
      /      *
    • Woodcutting class.
      */
      public Woodcut woodcut = new Woodcut();

    public void doStart() {
    System.out.println(“Options: [Save, Load, Inv, Contract, Mine]”);
    System.out.println(“More Options: [Shop, Woodcut, Sell itemname, Cheats, ?]”);
    String handler = getInput();
    if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“inv”)) {
    System.out.println(player.getInv());
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“mine”)) {
    mining.doMine(player);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“save”)) {
    fileops.doSave(player, contract);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“load”)) {
    fileops.doLoad(player, contract);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“shop”)) {
    shop.doShop(this, player);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“contract”)) {
    contract.doContract(player, this);
    } else if (handler.startsWith(“sell”)) {
    player.sellItem(handler.substring(5));
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“woodcut”)) {
    woodcut.doWoodcut(player);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase("?")) {
    System.out.println("| MyText - Version 1.0.0.1 - Now with cheats! |");
    //System.out.println("| Free to edit and release |");//
    } else if (handler.startsWith(“additem”)) {
    Player.addItem(handler.substring(8), “1”);
    methods.log(“Lol cheater”);
    } else if (handler.equalsIgnoreCase(“Cheats”)) {
    Cheats.askForCheats();
    }
    doStart();
    }

    /**

    • This is the basic get user input method.
    • No exception is reported in the case of an error.
    • Instead, a string of nothing is returned.
    • @return
      */
      public static String getInput() {
      try {
      BufferedReader input = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
      return input.readLine();
      } catch (IOException ex) {
      return “”;
      }
      }
      }
      [/code]

Also, make a new class called “methods” and paste this there:

public static void log(Object o) { System.out.println(o); }[/quote]
you suck.

zyle1992:

Also, if it requires comments to explain what’s going on, it’s bad code.

documentation of procedure and practice is hardly a bad thing, i’d rather be able to look at a basic synopsis than decipher someone else’s code, even if the code is fine.

zyle1992:

I program daily. I go to college, major in Software Development daily. I study with multiple professors who all have 30+ years of programming experience. I’m pretty sure I’m going to believe what they say over someone whose majority of “programming experience” revolves around a video game. I’m done with you. Honestly no need to continue on with such a hopeless argument. Read a bit more please.

no one cares what your professor can do, the likelihood that their experience and ability reflects yours is next to nothing, and nothing is a word that your ability is, quite probably, little more than.
